prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We cover continuous frequency range of 275-299 GHz (z=5.9-5.45 for [CII] line) by a set of scans, Set1-1, Set1-2 and Set1-3. Here we use a common TJ in these three SBs. We estimate the expected [CII] line emission based on the known relation between L_[CII] and L_FIR (See Figure 2). We estimate L_FIR from flux density at 1100 micron obtained by previous ALMA observation, we assume some possible spectral energy distribution (SED) modelsin the estimation (See Figure 1 and 2). As Figure 2 shows, we need to cover log(L_[CII]/L_FIR) of down to -3.0 - -3.8 as a function of L_FIR in order to detect [CII] line conservatively. As the result of estimations by using SED models, we find that a detection of L_[CII] = 1.6 x 10^9 Lo should cover possible area in the log(L_[CII]/L_FIR) - log(L_FIR) plot (See Figure 2, marked by colored bars). Here we assume a velocity width of 500 km/s and z=5.9 and obtained the expected peak flux of 3.5 mJy/beam for L_[CII] = 1.6 x 10^9 Lo. In order to detect the line with at least >4.5 sigma by two continuuous bin, we request 0.78 mJy/beam for bandwidth of 250 km/s. If we assume the typical log(L_[CII]/L_FIR) of known high-z galaxies is ~3 times larger than that we assume in this estimation, so the requested sensitivity is quite conservative and promising value.

Our science goal of this program is deteciton of [CII] line with an expected velocity width of ~500 km/s (FWHM) by a velocity resolution of ~250 km/s. So the spectral resolution of ~34 km/s is good enough. Our correlator set-up has small gap of 125 MHz (or~125 km/s). However, we think that this gap is negligible for our science goal.

We have already known the size of millimeter continuum, FWHM~0.2 arcsec in our target based on our ALMA cycle-1 program (Ikarashi et al. 2014). Here we assume the same size for [CII] emitting region. We aim detection of [CII] line, so we do not need higher angular resolution. In order to avoid loss of sensitivity by missing flux, angular resolution of >0.3 arcsec (FWHM) is preferable.

We cover continuous frequency range of 275-299 GHz (z=5.9-5.45 for [CII] line) by a set of scans, Set1-1, Set1-2 and Set1-3. Here we use a common TJ in these three SBs. We estimate the expected [CII] line emission based on the known relation between L_[CII] and L_FIR (See Figure 2). We estimate L_FIR from flux density at 1100 micron obtained by previous ALMA observation, we assume some possible spectral energy distribution (SED) modelsin the estimation (See Figure 1 and 2). As Figure 2 shows, we need to cover log(L_[CII]/L_FIR) of down to -3.0 - -3.8 as a function of L_FIR in order to detect [CII] line conservatively. As the result of estimations by using SED models, we find that a detection of L_[CII] = 1.6 x 10^9 Lo should cover possible area in the log(L_[CII]/L_FIR) - log(L_FIR) plot (See Figure 2, marked by colored bars). Here we assume a velocity width of 500 km/s and z=5.9 and obtained the expected peak flux of 3.5 mJy/beam for L_[CII] = 1.6 x 10^9 Lo. In order to detect the line with at least >4.5 sigma by two continuuous bin, we request 0.78 mJy/beam for bandwidth of 250 km/s. If we assume the typical log(L_[CII]/L_FIR) of known high-z galaxies is ~3 times larger than that we assume in this estimation, so the requested sensitivity is quite conservative and promising value.

We cover continuous frequency range of 275-299 GHz (z=5.9-5.45 for [CII] line) by a set of scans, Set1-1, Set1-2 and Set1-3. Here we use a common TJ in these three SBs. As Figure 2 shows, we need to cover log(L_[CII]/L_FIR) of down to -3.0 - -3.8 as a function of L_FIR in order to detect [CII] line conservatively. As the result of estimations by using SED models, we find that a detection of L_[CII] = 1.6 x 10^9 Lo should cover possible area in the log(L_[CII]/L_FIR) - log(L_FIR) plot (See Figure 2, marked by colored bars). Here we assume a velocity width of 500 km/s and z=5.9 and obtained the expected peak flux of 3.5 mJy/beam for L_[CII] = 1.6 x 10^9 Lo. In order to detect the line with at least >4.5 sigma by two continuuous bin, we request 0.78 mJy/beam for bandwidth of 250 km/s. If we assume the typical log(L_[CII]/L_FIR) of known high-z galaxies is ~3 times larger than that we assume in this estimation, so the requested sensitivity is quite conservative and promising value.

Our science goal of this program is deteciton of [CII] line with an expected velocity width of ~500 km/s (FWHM) by a velocity resolution of ~250 km/s. We aim detection of [CII] line, so we do not need higher angular resolution. In order to avoid loss of sensitivity by missing flux, angular resolution of >0.3 arcsec (FWHM) is preferable.

We cover continuous frequency range of 299-323 GHz (z=5.45-4.9 for [CII] line) by a set of scans, Set2-1, Set2-2 and Set2-3. Here we use a common TJ in these three SBs. We estimate the expected [CII] line emission based on the known relation between L_[CII] and L_FIR (See Figure 2). We estimate L_FIR from flux density at 1100 micron obtained by previous ALMA observation, we assume some possible spectral energy distribution (SED) modelsin the estimation (See Figure 1 and 2). As Figure 2 shows, we need to cover log(L_[CII]/L_FIR) of down to -3.0 - -3.8 as a function of L_FIR in order to detect [CII] line conservatively. As the result of estimations by using SED models, we find that a detection of L_[CII] = 1.6 x 10^9 Lo should cover possible area in the log(L_[CII]/L_FIR) - log(L_FIR) plot (See Figure 2, marked by colored bars). Here we assume a velocity width of 500 km/s and z=5.45 and obtained the expected peak flux of 4.0 mJy/beam for L_[CII] = 1.6 x 10^9 Lo. In order to detect the line with at least >4.5 sigma by two continuuous bin, we request 0.89 mJy/beam for bandwidth of 250 km/s. If we assume the typical log(L_[CII]/L_FIR) of known high-z galaxies is ~3 times larger than that we assume in this estimation, so the requested sensitivity is quite conservative and promising value.

Our science goal of this program is deteciton of [CII] line with an expected velocity width of ~500 km/s (FWHM) by a velocity resolution of ~250 km/s. So the spectral resolution of ~31 km/s is good enough. Our correlator set-up has small gap of 125 MHz (or~120 km/s). However, we think that this gap is negligible for our science goal.

We cover continuous frequency range of 243-275 GHz (z=6.8-5.9 for [CII] line) by a set of scans, Set4-1, Set4-2, Set4-3 and Set4-4. Here we use a common TJ in these four SBs. We estimate the expected [CII] line emission based on the known relation between L_[CII] and L_FIR (See Figure 2). We estimate L_FIR from flux density at 1100 micron obtained by previous ALMA observation, we assume some possible spectral energy distribution (SED) modelsin the estimation (See Figure 1 and 2). As Figure 2 shows, we need to cover log(L_[CII]/L_FIR) of down to -3.0 - -3.8 as a function of L_FIR in order to detect [CII] line conservatively. As the result of estimations by using SED models, we find that a detection of L_[CII] = 1.6 x 10^9 Lo should cover possible area in the log(L_[CII]/L_FIR) - log(L_FIR) plot (See Figure 2, marked by colored bars). Here we assume a velocity width of 500 km/s and z=6.8 and obtained the expected peak flux of 2.8 mJy/beam for L_[CII] = 1.6 x 10^9 Lo. In order to detect the line with at least >4.5 sigma by two continuuous bin, we request 0.62 mJy/beam for bandwidth of 250 km/s. If we assume the typical log(L_[CII]/L_FIR) of known high-z galaxies is ~3 times larger than that we assume in this estimation, so the requested sensitivity is quite conservative and promising value.

So the spectral resolution of ~36 km/s is good enough. Our correlator set-up has small gap of 125 MHz (or~144 km/s). However, we think that this gap is negligible for our science goal.

Our science goal of this program is deteciton of [CII] line with an expected velocity width of ~500 km/s (FWHM) by a velocity resolution of ~250 km/s. So the spectral resolution of ~36 km/s is good enough. Our correlator set-up has small gap of 125 MHz (or~144 km/s). However, we think that this gap is negligible for our science goal.

We have already known the size of millimeter continuum, FWHM~0.2 arcsec in our target based on our ALMA cycle-1 program (Ikarashi et al. 2014). Here we assume the same size for [CII] emitting region. We aim detection of [CII] line, so we do not need higher angular resolution. In order to avoid loss of sensitivity by missing flux, angular resolution of >0.3 arcsec (FWHM) is preferable.

The stacked Herschel SPIRE flux at 500 micron is 5 mJy (See Figure 1). So we request a r.m.s of 1 mJy/beam for continuum map to detect 5 mJy by 5sigma typically. It is worth mentioning that faintness or no detection at Band9 on some sources can be also useful to achieve our science goals.
We request simple Band-9 continuum observation. So default setting for Band-9 continuum observation is good enough.

We have already known the size of millimeter continuum, FWHM~0.2 arcsec in our target based on our ALMA cycle-1 program (Ikarashi et al. 2014). We aim detection of [CII] line, so we do not need higher angular resolution. In order to avoid loss of sensitivity by missing flux, angular resolution of >0.3 arcsec (FWHM) is preferable.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose redshift identification of ten z~6 candidate submillimeter galaxies (SMGs) discovered by AzTEC/ASTE and ALMA. Intensive observations of optical/near-infrared (NIR)-selected high redshift galaxies have traced cosmic star formation history (CSFH) up to z~7. However, dust-obscured CSFH at z>~4 remains unexplored. The target sources are extremely faint at optical/NIR/mid-infrared (MIR), and show extremely red color in stacked images such as [Ks]-[3.6] = 2.0?0.4. The estimated redshift derived from stacked optical/NIR/MIR SED is 6. Our targets are suitable to investigate how largely extremely red SMGs contribute to CSFH at z~6. We propose blind [CII] line surveys at Band6 and 7 by 13 tuning covering a frequency width of 98 GHz corresponding to cover z=4.3-6.8 by [CII] line in order to identify redshift. We also propose Band 9 continuum observation to support redshift identification by submillimeter color at Band 6, 7 and 9 and to characterize dust SED. Our proposed program can yield 10 z~6 SMG sample and put a lower limit on dust-obscured CSFH at z~6, for example, >4.4x10^-3 M_sun yr^{-1} Mpc^-3 if all of the targets turned out to be at z=6.0+/-0.5.
